title: The Business of Rugby: How South African Teams Have Boosted URC Profits to an All-Time High ·
text:
When it was announced in 2021 that the Pro14 would be rebranded as the United Rugby Championship (URC), with South Africa’s top franchises joining the European-based competition, the decision was met with a wave of scepticism.
Some of the loudest criticism came from Ulster, where club officials were wary of disrupting the traditional structure of European rugby by including teams from the Southern Hemisphere in what was seen as a sacred competition.
South African Franchises Improve URC Standard
The South African perspective implied that the reservations were driven more by a fear of competition than by a genuine desire to preserve the integrity of European rugby.
To some extent, it might have been a justified retort as every final since has been contested by a South African side. Tellingly, this doesn’t look like changing in 2025 as the Pretoria-based Bulls are one of the favourites to win the URC at 5/1 with Paddy Power betting odds.
As for what these odds mean, you can use an online returns tool provided by the Irish bookmaker to calculate bets so that you better understand probability, whether they’re singles, doubles, or even accumulators using an acca calculator. On this occasion, a £5 single bet on the Bulls to win the 2025 URC at 5/1 would show a return of £30 in total, including a £25 profit.
In other words, the expectation around South African teams winning the URC is so high that you’re unlikely to win a fortune should they do so. The Stormers did, after all, win the very first edition of the URC in 2022 when they beat the Bulls in Cape Town.
The reality is that the inclusion of teams from the Rainbow Nation has undoubtedly raised the standard of the URC on the pitch which is no surprise when you consider that South Africa are back-to-back world champions. As a result, the URC now stands among the highest-quality rugby leagues globally.
However, when considering the scenario purely from a business perspective, has it made economic sense?
Record Revenue
The answer is an unequivocal “yes,” according to Martin Anayi, CEO of the URC. Speaking in December, Anayi revealed that more than half of the league’s revenue now comes from South Africa.
This surge is largely attributed to the URC’s lucrative television deal with South African broadcaster Supersport. Additionally, the inclusion of South African teams in the URC has seen the arrival of new sponsors from the Rainbow Nation, namely Vodacom, which is a South African-based telecommunications company with a monopoly on the industry.
Crucially, this influx of new sponsors extends beyond the URC given that South African teams have also been granted permission to compete in the European Rugby Champions Cup (EPCR).
As a result of these teams being given the green light to compete on the continent, Johannesburg-based international bank and wealth management company Investec stepped in as the league’s title sponsor.
The Bottom Line
Undoubtedly, the financial knock-on effect from the decision—an admittedly unorthodox one to allow Southern Hemisphere teams to compete in a European tournament—has been far-reaching.
Even those in Ulster, who had initially expressed justified concerns about the amalgamation, will now see the benefits of having teams from the most successful rugby nation on earth playing in their league.
Indeed, wherever the best players on the planet go, the money is never too far behind, and right now, the URC has become a product that is watched in every corner of the globe.
The question now might be why this decision wasn’t made sooner as the URC revenue is now the highest of all time.
